references: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
Pope, D.H. and S.H. Pope. 1951. A study of the salamander Plethodon ouachitae and the description of an allied form. Bulletin of the Chicago Academy of Science 9:129-152.

Anthony, C.D. 2005. Plethodon caddoensis (Pope and Pope 1951), Caddo Mountain Salamander. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 792-793.
IUCN. 2014. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1. http://www.iucnredlist.org. Downloaded March 2016.
Saugey, D.A., G.A. Heidt, and D.R. Heath. 1985. Summer use of abandoned mines by the Caddo Mountain salamander, Plethodon caddoensis (Plethodontidae) in Arkansas. Southewestern Naturalist 30:318-319.

Plummer, M.V. 1982. The status of the Caddo Mountain and Fourche Mountain salamanders (Plethodon caddoensis, P. fourchensis) in Arkansas. Report to the Arkansas Natural Heritage Commission, Little Rock, Arkansas.
Heath, D.R., D.A. Saugey and G.A. Heidt. 1986. Abandoned mine fauna of the Ouachita Mountains, Arkansas: vertebrate taxa. Proceedings of the Arkansas Academy of Science 40:33–36.
Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
Spotila, J.R. 1972. Role of temperature and water in the ecology of lungless salamanders. Ecological Monographs 42:95-125.
habitat_description: Endemic to the Caddo Mountains of Polk and Montgomery counties in Arkansas, P. caddoensis inhabits north-facing, cool, mesic, mature mixed deciduous, wooded slopes which are often rocky and talus covered (Pope and Pope 1951, Spotila 1972, Plummer 1982, Wilson 1995, Petranka 1998, Anthony 2005). This species utilizes the spaces between rocks, logs, and other debris for cover and moisture retention but will also retreat to abandoned mines and caves (Saugey et al. 1985, Heath et al. 1986).
